I don't like having new rules of time travel every time I watch a new show. It is bad writing. There are certain things that are common in time travel shows or movies.
1) Time loops. Examples: Terminator 1, 12 Monkeys. When you have a time loop, you can go back in time but your actions end up causing the events you intended to prevent. Every loop is exactly the same.
2) Alternative time lines. Examples: Time Cop, Time Cop 2. The idea of an alternative time line is basically "What if?" such as "What if the Nazis won WWII?" In this scenario, if you go back in time and change the past then you create a new time line and when you return to the present everything has changed.
3) Many Worlds. Examples: Terminator 3, Terminator: Genisys. In this scenario, you go back and change the past but the future remains unchanged. Why?
Basically, it is because the old time line and the new time line exist in parallel. Think Schrodinger's cat. When you open the box the cat is either alive or dead but until you open the box the cat is in a mixed state: it is neither dead nor alive.
Logically, in this scenario it is impossible to actually change the past because doing so would violate causality: if you change the past then why do you go back in time in the first place? At least the Many Worlds Interpretation of Quantum Mechanics allows us to go back in time and superficially make changes even if the future remains unchanged. We can say that once you have seen the future then the future becomes inevitable and no matter what you do differently the future you saw will always come to pass.
These are the rules that good sci fi shows and movies follow because they make sense. Shows and movies will add their own rules not because they make sense but because they are required for the narrative. For example, a lot of shows and movies claim that it takes a while for the time line to "set" and that gives you time to change things back but that's not based on any known physics and is just a narrative device designed to create tension.

Sometimes you watch a movie in the theater and think "This is really bad" and then you see it again on TV and you think "It's not terrible." Sometimes the anger you feel having to pay to see an awful movie angers you more than having to watch the same movie when there's nothing else on. That's been my experience with The Incredible Hulk and Iron Man II. It helps that the Hulk went on to be better in the Avengers and that Thunderbolt Ross, Rhodey, Tony and Natasha were all in Civil War because you appreciate those movies as preludes to better movies.

I disagree. The current Marvel Now has the All New All Different Avengers with Falcon, Miles Morales, Ms Marvel and Nova. It is inevitable that we will see less of Captain America, the Vision, the Hulk, Iron Man and Thor as the actors who play them age. Also, Marvel has been introducing a lot of new characters (including female and "ethnic" characters) in the comics that they will eventually want to use in movies.

It would be like saying "Let's do an Iron Man movie" and then saying that it is off the table because they've already done three. I suppose you could argue that Runaways is not "off the table" because it is still in development and thus very much on the table. But we know what he meant.

Moon Knight: This has long been rumored as a Netflix series.
Nova: Well, we do have the Nova Corps from Guardians of the Galaxy and we will have the Guardians in Avengers: Infinity War so we will see what develops in Phase 4.
She Hulk: The Hulk solo movie had set up a possible She Hulk spin off very well. Banner wanted his blood destroyed but I really doubt if Thunderbolt Ross had the blood destroyed seeing as how that was what he wanted all along. With Banner's blood he can make more Hulks including Hulks that don't lose their mind in the process.
Ghost Rider: This is strongly rumored to be an upcoming Netflix series. If they bring Ghost Rider back on Agents of SHIELD and they get a ratings bump then perhaps Netflix will agree to distribute a Ghost Rider series. As was the case with the Punisher, an actor is already cast and fans are happy with him. They just need to cast Johnny Blaze for the flashbacks.
Blade: The Darkhold is supposed to be dangerous but how dangerous is it? Is it dangerous enough to release a horde of vampires on Earth. Will we have Blade come out of retirement saying he is "too old for this shit" so he will train a new team of Nightstalkers? Sounds like a plot for Agents of SHIELD Season 5. If it works it could be spun off into a Netflix series.
Thunderbolts: Well, we do have Punisher and Elektra. Another possible addition would be Spider-Woman and the previously mentioned Moon Knight. Let's have the Thunderbolts from the Punisher / Elektra run go up against the Dark Avengers who were the original Thunderbolts from the comics. Marvel might not be allowed to use Norman Osborn in a Netflix series so we could have Wilson "Kingpin" Fisk form the Dark Avengers instead.
Taskmaster: Ant Man / Hawkeye villain. Obvious choice for Ant Man 3 if not Ant Man and the Wasp.
Venom: Problematic. They could introduce Venom in a Spider-Man movie and then have Venom face the Avengers but Marvel's deal with Sony doesn't say anything about a Venom movie.
Sinister Six: Problematic. They could introduce the Sinister Six in a Spider-Man movie and then have the Sinister Six face the Avengers but Marvel's deal with Sony doesn't say anything about a Sinister Six movie.
New Avengers: You mean other than the Defenders, the Guardians, the Runaways and the New Warriors? Seriously, I could see Spider-Man, Nova, Quasar, White Tiger, Ms. Marvel, Kate Bishop and Miles Morales being a new iteration of the Avengers in the distant future with Spider-Man taking the role of Tony Stark and Miles being his Rhodey. Or maybe they will save Kate Bishop for a Young Avengers TV show.

Why on Earth would Marvel sell the merchandising rights to Namor when they never sold the merchandising rights to X-Men or Spider-Man? Please stop speculating. If you don't know who the "other parties" are then just say so. Don't pretend you know any more than anybody else at this point.
If Marvel's deal is with Sony Pictures then it remains in place no matter who buys Sony Pictures unless there is a clause that says otherwise.

Wow. We finally know how the Sony / Marvel deal works.
If Marvel wants to use Spider-Man in Civil War then they need to make a Spider-Man movie. If Marvel wants to use Spider-Man in Infinity War then they need to make another Spider-Man movie. Apparently Marvel will have to do a movie for Sony every time they use Spider-Man in an MCU movie they will have to do a movie for Sony.
Alas this means that Norman Osborn could not be a villain in Avengers movies unless he came as a package with Spider-Man. On the other hand, if Marvel did a Sinister Six movie for Sony they could presumably have the Avengers fight the Sinister Six in an MCU movie,
Marvel's deal with Constantin Films for the Fantastic Four is different, of course. If Marvel waits until 2025 then they will be able to start using the Fantastic Four in the MCU. Feige might want the rights back before 2025 but Disney isn't going to want to spend money to buy back rights that they can just wait for. If Fox starts working on a new Fantastic Four movie then the situation could change. Disney could allow Feige to produce a Fantastic Four film for Fox in exchange for a Fantastic Four cameo in an MCU movie. If Fox wanted a sequel then they would have to let Marvel have another cameo and so on. That could work.

http://comicsalliance.com/namor-movie-rights-universal-marvel-studios/
Talk of a Namor movie first surfaced in 1997, and several scripts were written but ultimately unused, and the character was optioned by Universal in 2001 at a time when the superhero boom was just taking off thanks to the likes of Blade and X-Men. Marvel was recovering from near-bankruptcy at this point, and the sale of the movie rights to characters including Hulk, Spider-Man and the Fantastic Four helped keep it afloat.
Development of a Namor movie stalled for several years until 2004, when Christopher Columbus was brought in to direct a film based on a script by David Self. Columbus left the project a year later and was replaced by Jonathan Mostow, but again the project was seemingly dead in the water (sorry) for a number of years.
In 2012, at a convention in the UK, Joe Quesada claimed that the rights to Namor had lapsed and reverted to Marvel Studios. Paul Rubin, a concept designer, gave an interview to ComicBook.com where he talked about his work on Universals Namor movie, and described his planned approach.
its a little bit medieval, its a little bit of a fairy tale kind of a setting both in the social structure and also in the way everything is designed. To take that and to find a cool, science fictional grounding for it
In 2013, Kevin Feige confirmed that Namor was still at Universal while answering questions about the future of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. ...
In May 2014, it was rumoured that Universal Studios and Legendary Pictures were teaming up to make a Namor film, but that was refuted less than two weeks later by Kevin Feige, who said in an interview with IGN that Marvel once again had the rights to Namor but it was still a complicated matter they were working to untangle.
Yes, but its slightly more complicated than that. Lets put it this way there are entanglements that make it less easy. There are older contracts that still involve other parties that mean we need to work things out before we move forward on it. As opposed to an Iron Man or any of the Avengers or any of the other Marvel characters where we could just put them in.
These complications probably explain why Namor, like the X-Men and the Fantastic Four, has been absent from all recent Marvel video games and animation.
This week Joe Quesada confirmed that he thinks the rights are back at Marvel in his interview with Kevin Smith, but he was rather uncertain in his language.
I cant speak for studios As far as I know, yeah we do. Its not at Fox, its not at Sony Yeah.
Joe Quesada is Marvels chief creative officer, so the rights to the characters are certainly in his remit, but the answer isnt as definitive as some fans may like, and Quesada has been wrong on this matter in the past.
When asked whether fans might see Namor in the movies soon, all Quesada would say is that he cannot confirm or deny, which still leaves the future of the character in doubt.
Source: Fishy Situation: What's The Deal With Namor's Movie Rights? | http://comicsalliance.com/namor-movie-rights-universal-marvel-studios/?trackback=tsmclip
When Feige says "other parties" that definitely includes Universal but I am confused as to whom else it refers to.

The problem is not that Universal does not want Marvel to make a Hulk movie. The problem is that Hulk movies are not profitable enough to justify making when they have to share the profits with Universal. Universal has the same problem with Namor. They would like to do a Namor movie but they really don't know how to to go about doing it and Marvel doesn't think it is a strong enough property to justify doing a stand alone movie when they would have to share profits with Universal.

The comics and movies already are political.
Stan Lee created a character called the Black Panther. There was a Black Panther party in the U.S. at the time.
Speaking of the Black Panther Party, there was a similar organisation in the Avenger comics. They and a KKK analog were revealed to both be working for the Hate Monger.
When Stan Lee created the X-Men, he had Martin Luther King and Malcolm X in mind as models for Professor Xavier and Magneto. Later versions of the X-Men made the analogy with homosexuality, especially the scene in X-Men 2 where Bobby came out to his parents as a mutant. Brian Singer is gay in real life.
The Secret Empire in the comics was a clear jab at the Republican Party in that the President in 70s Captain America comics was said to be a member of the Secret Empire. We never saw the President's face and this implied that the President in question was in fact Nixon. (George Bush senior appeared in a 90s Avengers comic so they weren't doing fictional presidents in the comics.)
Mutant Registration and Superhero registration and their consequences hearken back to the the treatment of Native Americans, the Nazi holocaust, the internment of Japanese Americans during WWII and the persecution of illegal immigrants.
The Watchdogs on Agents of SHIELD are basically a right wing extremist group. The Inhumans are essentially Muslims in that they are, ironically, branded as terrorists by the Watchdogs. The comics even have a character who is both Inhuman and Muslim.
Earth-9997 Norman Osborn did become President of the United States.
In the mainstream comics, Norman Osborn became the government appointed director of the Thunderbolts following Civil War. He later became Director of SHIELD and the head of national security in the US, became Iron Patriot, was put in charge of the Avengers 50 state initiative and formed the Dark Avengers using the original members of the Thunderbolts. He later formed his own X-Men team with members consisting mostly of X-Men villains.
http://marvel.wikia.com/wiki/Norman_Osborn_(Earth-616)

For now, the companys film and television arms continue to make sure each of the superhero stories can stand alone, no matter the size of the screen. We certainly communicate with each other in terms of what were doing and what we have planned and the characters that were using and where its all going, Loeb says of working with Marvel Studios president Kevin Feige, who oversees the films. That helps limit the fatigue, but also poses a personal problem for Loeb: Unfortunately for me as a fan, he says, I tend to know more about whats happening in the movies than I want to know. Only fans receive spoiler alerts, after all.
http://ew.com/tv/2017/01/13/defenders-marvel-cinematic-universe-crossover-jeph-loeb/
Is Glenn Close confirmed for Infinity War?
Incredibly, nobody has mentioned the massive (literal) hole in Daredevil Season 2.
He's not that kind of doctor.

Lady of the Lake Killer
From Agent Carter Season 2? I thought it was clear that she was exposed to dark matter or whatever they called it.
Last we saw him, he was missing a leg.

Black Widow is also missing
Is she?
That sounds tedious. There should be a montage in which he collects the first five stones.

I would prefer something with a tight pace. Consider Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice: the story was unnecessarily convoluted and the movie outstayed its welcome. If I had to guess as to what the plot of Infinity War was going to be I would say that it involved Thanos collecting five of the six gems and then he battles the Avengers in order to get the mind gem from Vision. Incredibly the Avengers turn out to be too much for him. Presumably Thanos returns a year later in Avengers 4 to try again. Thing is, Marvel has promised that Avengers 4 will be "very different" rom Avengers: Infinity War and not just be Infinity War Part II. If so then it is too early to speculate as to how Avengers: Infinity War ends. Maybe it ends with Thanos getting killed off and Avengers 4 deals with the aftermath. We'll see.

What do you think of the Netflix MCU and do you think any of those characters are going to make the big screen transition?
KEVIN FEIGE: I think its extremely impressive what Netflix has done and it will be the same answer I always give, which is, It all depends on timing. It all depends on how to do it because I dont think what anybody wants to do is have such important characters show up for one second. Black Panther and Spider-Man to me are the high bar in Civil War of how you can bring in new characters into something. Vision and Ultron, Wanda and Pietro in Ultron. And it takes a lot of screentime, and it takes a lot of work. Infinity War has a lot of people in it already. So it just depends on how we could figure it out.
http://collider.com/marvel-netflix-mcu-crossover-kevin-feige/

Another issue is time. I mean, there were already 12 heroes in Captain America: Civil War. Introducing Luke Cage in addition to Spider-Man and Black Panther would have taken up a lot of screen time in what was ultimately a Captain America movie. It would be easier, logistically, for movie characters to appear on TV or Netflix but whereas TV and Netflix actors DO have it in their contracts that they could be asked to appear in movies, the movie stars don't have it in their contract that they could be asked to appear on TV or Netflix. That means separate deals have to be signed. So far, Samuel Jackson, Cobie Smulders and Jamie Alexander have agreed to appear on Agents of SHIELD. The fact that Marvel doesn't bring their characters back on the show suggests that they may be expensive.

WRITING.TITLE: The Defenders: How Claire Temple fits into the series

WRITING.TEXT: tldr

Certainly the US State Department, the CIA and the international business community could use more Russian, Chinese and Arabic speakers; languages that the Foreign Service Institute has categorized as some of the most difficult to master.
Yet a May 2015 article from the Atlantic finds from 2008 and 2013 statistics -- a significant drop of foreign second language usage from K-12 onwards. While 93% of high schools provided these classes, only 7% of college students continued language studies. Only 1% of American adults today, who studied languages in school, are proficient bilinguals.
http://newamericamedia.org/2015/12/american-bilingualism.php
Learning a foreign language takes dedication. Most people in the US only speak English even though they probably studied a foreign language in high school.
I'm not the one who is coming across as ignorant and racist.
Daisy Johnson did?
While living in the US.

He was a strong lead.
Look, Marvel superheroes from the sixties weren't physically imposing. Mr. Fantastic, Spider-Man, Tony Stark, Bruce Banner, Hank Pym, they were all science nerds. Thor had the secret identity of Don Blake. Captain America started out as skinny Steve Rogers. Marvel heroes are supposed to be relatable. Quite frankly, unless you are some sort of body builder, a physically imposing character of any race would not be someone you could picture yourself as.
Wow. You're coming across as extremely obnoxious and racist here.
But on top of learning to be a super spy you want her to learn Mandarin.

One problem with imposing characters of any race is that they lack relatability. Ward was disliked when he first appeared on Agents of SHIELD because people couldn't relate to him. Wong is an every man with a job. (He looks after magic books and makes sure nobody steals them.) He is very relatable.
He had a photographic memory.
I speak English, French and Mandarin so I can say with confidence that learning a foreign language isn't as easy as you seem to think it is.
You are disparaging sloppy looking men.
Magic isn't uniquely Asian.

During the Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. panel at New York Comic-Con, Marvel TV head Jeph Loeb responded to a question on the topic, simply saying, Fair question. The answer is: Stay tuned. In a roundtable interview with Screen Rant, Loeb additionally commented on the subject of an Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. crossover with the Netflix universe:
I get in trouble every single time I say this, which is #ItsAllConnected. But trust me when I say #ItsAllConnected and thats about all I can say on it at this time.
The Its All Connected hashtag became popularized thanks to Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.s tie-in episodes with the larger cinematic universe films, especially in the early seasons. However, S.H.I.E.L.D. has moved away from specific tie-in episodes, and recently opted to showcase the impacts of Captain America: Civil War through mentioning the Sokovia Accords and the events of the film. Elaborating on the difficulties of making sure everything in the MCU is connected and crafting crossovers, Loeb said:
One of the things thats a challenge and its unlike the movie studio because the movie studio is making all of the movies for one place and thats the theaters. The theater owners dont get to say well we dont want Spider-Man to be in Captain America in that particular case Sony and Marvel had to work that out so that could happen. But in the case of what we do, we have networks to consider and thats a conversation [for] ABC and Netflix and now we have shows at Hulu and Freeform and FX [as well]. So it just becomes a question of once it starts, what have we unleashed? But its certainly a topic of conversation.
http://screenrant.com/agents-shield-marvel-netflix-crossover-jeph-loeb/

http://screenrant.com/agents-shield-marvel-netflix-crossover-jeph-loeb/
